subject: RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy
msgSnippet: David wrote: Here is the crux of the problem with your argument.  As far as I understand unit testing using an xUnit framework and as part of the XP process.
messageBody:
David wrote:

Here is the crux of the problem with your argument. As far as I
understand unit testing using an xUnit framework and as part of the XP
process. The existence of test interdependencies (outside of thread
testing) is a code smell which is avoided. If the xUnit framework
were
to support the concept of dependencies it would be promoting a
specific
code smell which it is intende to avoid.

I don't think a truer word has been spoken in this thread. I think you are
spot on. I think I trod in some "test *content* dependency" stigma, when I
was discussing run order "test dependency order", which I don't feel is the
same.

I am not saying my tests depends upon the run of another, no side effects, I
am saying "if my fruit class fails why bother testing my apple class? It has
a rotten core." It kinda goes back to Bertrand Russell... If I know fruit is
bad, then the fact that apple succeeds doesn't make it a healthy apple, it
is unknown.

Still, I don't think the idea has a chance of a fair hearing.

In Kent Beck's book Test Driven Development by Example one of the
TDD
patterns is called Isolated Test, he asks the question: "How
should the
running of your tests affect one another?" and answers himself:
"Not at
all." If you have to test a series of functions as a group which
have
to all be completed to constitute success, then do those all in
one
testFunction.

I agree in principle. That said, I tests in layers, building on each other.
I can't put 1000 tests in one testcase, just as I would put 1000 class in
one package. I just wanted to bring run order through simple statements of
dependency. I think you see what I was saying, and you've explained why I am
getting nowhere.

That really is it. No dependency concept exists, because it is
something to discourage. Dependencies are a sign that the code needs
more decoupling and more refactoring.

Point taken on discouragement, and boy -- yes -- I've felt that. ;-)

I think test content dependency is wrong, but not what I am saying. Either
that, or you decouple yourself from everything you do, a purist goal of no
real world value. Code used code, that is a dependency.

In the example, in Kent's book he relays the experience of having a
test
suite that would run overnight, and sometimes nothing would break and
other times he'd get a printout of many pages with all of his bugs.
It
turned out that the large printout usually meant one test failed and
caused cascading failures through the rest of the tests due to
dependencies.

This is all about test content dependency -- side effects -- and I never
meant that. Why get a fruit basket full of errors when fruit is bad? I was
actually trying to reduce this mess of an output to "the *possible* root
cause -- and if nothing else, a place to start cleaning up".

Thanks, you saved me from trying further...

regards

Adam
